bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 9, 1899

div1.p: Reed writes that he misses her and that he is imagining how beautiful things are back at home. He mentions the Dreyfuss Affair and says the journalists believe France is close to revolution.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 9, 1899
div1.p:
It does
seem so strange that at this
hour, 7.20 P.M, I am not
sitting in our little dining-
room at Keewaydin, talking
to the dearest Farmer-lady
& sweetest little Japanese
Maiden in all the land!
But never mind; when I
come up this time, I'll hope
to stay longer with my
precious babies- The day
has been so cool & lovely
here, and as it was
entirely unexpected, it was
the more gratefully appreciated.
This afternoon was clear & beau-
tiful & I know it must have
been so on the mountain- Your
darling letter of last night
came this afternoon- I am
so glad that Mrs. Halstead
will stay till after my birth-
day- Won't that be nice!
I have the Major's Field
glasses to bring up with
me on Tuesday- We can
then see the valley sure enough!
I had another talk with
Dr Sternberg, this morning-
He has promised that I
can go by way of Japan -
so that I can visit Kitisato
at Tokio- I don't know whether
he will allow the hospital ship
Missouri to go to Yokohama or
not, but as we won't leave
New York till Septr 20th, the
Lord only knows when she will
get back to San Francisco-
Certainly not before January
1st, at the earliest-

Well, the court martial has
found Dreyfus guilty & sen-
tenced him to 10 years Impris-
onment- Isn't it dreadful?
But, of course, the Supreme
Court will set the verdict
aside. Things are now
ripe for a revolution in
France; at least so say the
Newspaper Correspondents-
Well, what have you been
doing with yourself these fine
days? Working any in Grotto
Park? How about the path
to Tower-view? Cut down
any more trees? What is
fat buster doing? Get ready
to have a big cake for next
Wednesday, and Cabbage, or
there will be trouble at
Keewayden! I'll write again
tomorrow, but not on Monday-
Love to Mrs. Halstead- Kisses
and love for my precious
babies- Boo! Boo! you loves!
